A lot of people are saying yes, but I don't think they fully understand the question. If you are evil, than that means you intentionally do morally wrong things, at least, that's how I see it. If this is what you "want" than it can make you happy. But "want" is in a matter of perspective. Nobody, unless they have a mental illness, wants to be evil. Even if you ask someone who claims they are evil why they did things, they will most likely try to reason and back themselves up with moral correctness. In most cases, people have merely convinced themselves they want immorality. But "deep down" that isn't what their mind/heart needs to feel satisfied, so they will come off as angry at the world or a generally negative person.  Now, if immorality isn't what they really need to be happy, then by getting it (and thus being evil) they are not becoming truly happy, no matter what they convince themselves of. Thus, they are not really happy.  So most people who are "evil" are not really evil, and go about acting like it only finding a false happiness.  Your answer is mostly no.

In nearly every story that I have seen, evil people are usually maniacally laughing or being very smug and arrogant with how well their masterplan is being carried out (before ultimately being stopped by the hero, hobbit, normal person). It looks like they are really happy at being evil! Happiness, after all, is a state of mind. In real life though, how evil people react depends very much on who they seek recognition from. If they have close peers who themselves support and encourage the evil behavior, then of course, it becomes a positive (evil) feedback loop for them, causing them to be happy. But if they are lonesome, their point of feedback would be society itself, which would look  at them in disdain, and this provides a negative feedback loop for them, causing them to be unhappy. For example, If you read some of the personal thoughts of serial killers, they talk about how they feel like they are being controlled by the devil, etc. But as always, this isn't a hard and fast rule about all evil guys.

I think they believe themselves to be happy, but because they always want more than they have, the happiness is very brief, until they achieve the next evil gain. They will never feel they have enough, so there will always be a feeling of anxiety, needing the next 'fix' of whatever their evil demands. There is no feeling of reaching a final goal, so there is no moment when they can, at last, rest and find peace. Actually, now that I think about it, it seems to me a truly evil person creates his own, inescapable Hell, from which he can never be free.

They might derive pleasure out of what they do, as would anybody else, but they are certainly not happy. Anand Tamariya's answer to What does it take to achieve happiness? There is a subtle difference between pleasure and happiness. A tickle can give pleasure, but it's not happiness. Heck, a massage session, a spa treatment, binge drinking or any other hedonistic activity can only give momentary pleasure not lasting happiness. Even a fantastic victory achieved by wrong means can be tumultuous for a person. Lance Armstrong's, a cancer survivor and seven times winner of Tour-de-France, confession gives you an idea about the torn person he'd become because of the means he had adopted. And that happens to any person with a mind-body-soul conflict.

No, according to Socrates. Only virtuous people can be happy. And you need to have all the virtues (courage, temperance, justice, wisdom, etc.), not just one or two, to succeed in that endeavor. A virtuous life is a well-lived life; it’s rational, social, humble, intelligent, and proven to work. A vicious life makes all the existential and ethical mistakes: greediness, pride, vengeance, unforgivingness, intellectual laziness, cowardice, ignorance, stupidity, etc. A vicious life is an unhappy life, despite the fact that the vicious person may have wealth, fame, and power.

This question is spooky to me because of the ideas it brings me to consider. I’ve had enough trouble in my life. I don’t even want to judge anybody anymore. Especially not a purely evil person or entity or thing. I’m sorry. Enough is enough and too much stinks as some wise man said!
